text: A reference to the parable of new wine into old wineskins found in [Luke 5:36–39](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Luke%205%3A36-39&version=NIV): "And he spake also a parable unto them; No man putteth a piece of a new garment upon an old; if otherwise, then both the new maketh a rent, and the piece that was taken out of the new agreeth not with the old. And no man putteth new wine into old bottles; else the new wine will burst the bottles, and be spilled, and the bottles shall perish." This line has entered the Slavic canon also thanks to the ["Sermon of Law and Grace"](http://sites.utoronto.ca/elul/English/218/Ilarion.pdf) attributed to Hilarion (XI century), where we read: "Ибо не вливают, по словам Господним, вина учения нового, благодатного в мехи ветхие, обветшавшие в иудействе: прорываются мехи, и вино вытекает." On another level, this line is suggestive of Sokolov's approach to art. That is, new forms (proetry, for example) are necessary to express new content, much as *Between Dog and Wolf* challenges readers with its innovative style and form. Of course, paring Yakov (the Drunken Huntsman) with Hilarion is a debatable and possibly ironic choice. In an interview with Ivan Podshivalov, Sokolov said the following regarding Alexander Solzhenitsyn: "Solzhenitsyn tries: He writes; he makes an effort to keep pace with new literary current. He obviously takes pains to adopt new forms, assimilate avant-garde devices, but none of that suits him. Is it possible to pour new wine into old wineskins" (Podshivalov, "A Conversation" 356). On the subject of "proetry" and genre, Sokolov had the following to say: "Genres boundaries have eroded, and there is not need to reestablish them. The time has come for a new period of synthesis. As I explained genre interests me less than the kinds of works I write. I create *proetry* (*proezia*). This term is my discovery. Although, of course, I am far from being the first, and, more likely, I am the last in a long line of followers of the tradition that includes Turgenev and Bunin. Earlier, there were verses in prose, yet it remained prose. I think of myself as a *proet* (Podshivalov, "A Conversation," 352). Elsewhere, however, Sokolov has expressed a view that underscores literary lineage: "For me language is a kind of symphony, and it works out that I'm writing variations on its themes. I don't think that in principle something new comes out of it. You can only dream of something new. Anyone who writes is limited by the nature of speech" (Litus, "Snezhnyi 382).

Orina's body arouses Ilya. Beyond being considered a silly or stupid animal, the goose has other resonances. According to Rowland, the goose has been seen as "an erotic symbol for both sexes, because it was the bird of creation, whether in the male solar form of the gods or the female lunar form of the mother goddesses" (68).
